turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: He knew the penalty for breaking regulations.  He ought to pay without sending you to beg.

turns.speaker: CORA
turns.text: You know he wouldn't send me...! You misrepresented what you saw and caused this.  I, too, was at that farm. It was as he said...

turns.speaker: CORA
turns.text: They do not live their lives "by your leave."  ...They hack it out of the wilderness with their own two hands, burying their dead and their children along the way.

turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: You are defending him because you've become infatuated with him.

turns.speaker: CORA
turns.text: Yes. Go ahead.

turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: What the bloody hell plan is this?

turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: ... compliments, Mr. Poe.  Take her and get out.

turns.speaker: CORA
turns.text: What are they doing to Duncan? Duncan!

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: Your wounded should try walkin' back to Albany.  They'll never make a passage north.

turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: We were headed...

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: ...Fort William Henry.

turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: How far is it, scout?

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: Day and a half  Where did you get... the guide?

turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: Colonel Munro sent him. He was one of our Mohawk allies.

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: He is Huron and nothing else.  Why would he want to murder the girl?

turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: What?!

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: Dark haired...

turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: Miss Cora Munro. He never set eyes on her before today.

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: No blood vengeance? No re-proach or insult?

turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: Of course not!  And how is it you were nearby?

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: Came across the war party, tracked 'em.

turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: Then you're assigned to Fort William Henry?

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: Fort Edward, then?

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: No. Headin' west. To Can-tuck-ee.

turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: I thought all our colonial scouts were in the militia?

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: I ain't your "scout". And I am in no damn militia.

turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: Then you are one of those who would allow England to fight alone while she protects you from France?

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: England does not protect me and does not war against France on our account. She uses us to war against France on her own account...  of greed for land and furs.

turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: I owe you gratitude or I'd call you out!

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: Do not let gratitude get in the way...

turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: Who were these people?

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: Ottawa!

turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: Excuse me...

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: And if English law cannot be trusted, maybe these people would do better makin' a peace with the French!

turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: That is sedition! Treason!

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: That is the truth!

turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: I ought to have you whipped from this fort!

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: Major!  Some day I think you and I are gonna have a serious disagreement.

turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: How long?

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: Only chance we got is...  ... to get more distance on 'em and go to ground!

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: Head for... for the white water.

turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: Do you hear me, sir!  If you ever fall... into British hands...  What white water?

turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: Where do we go from here?

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: We don't.

turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: I don't understand!

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: This is it, as far as we can go... If we're lucky, they'll be figurin' we can't have come this way and must've beached our canoes and headed cross land. If we're very lucky, they'll figure we went over the falls.

turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: Then what?

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: Then we take the south rim down the mountain and it's 12 miles cross country to Fort Edward.

turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: And if we're unlucky?

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: You will have to forego the pleasure of hangin' me.

turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: Any powder?

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: : Only one or two loads.

turns.speaker: LIEUTENANT
turns.text: It should be enough to remind you France is the enemy.

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: Your enemy...

turns.speaker: LIEUTENANT
turns.text: What did you say?

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: I said... France is your enemy. Not ours.

turns.speaker: LIEUTENANT
turns.text: Really? Do you want them to overrun all New York colony?

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: First place, you started it with the French over fur-trapping claims to the head waters of the Ohio.  Now you're sayin' these people have a fight on their hands...

turns.speaker: LIEUTENANT
turns.text: Will you men help us stop the French?

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: ... and while they are cooped up in your fort, what if the French send war parties to raid their homes?

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: You do what you want with your own scalp.  Do not be tellin' us what to do with ours.

turns.speaker: LIEUTENANT
turns.text: You, sir! You call yourself a loyal subject?

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: ...No...Do not call myself much of a subject at all.

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: That we did. John. But the horicane  is near trapped out.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Tradin' your skins in Castleton?

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: So what is it, Jack? What brings you up here?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: A French & Indian army out of Fort Carillon's heading south to war against the English. I'm here to raise this county's militia to aid the British defense.

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: Folks here goin' to join in that fight?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: We'll see in the morning...

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: I believe if they set aside their law as and when they wish, their law no longer has rightful authority over us. All they have over us is tyranny, then. And I'll stay here no longer.  No force on earth will keep me here... Anyone caught leavin' the fort could be shot. So each man make your own decision... Those who are goin', be back here in an hour.

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: Out the northern sally-port. Strike for the east side of the swamp until you clear the French picket line. Head north over the ridge, then come about southeast and fork left in Little Meadow and you're free of the outpost and skirmishers...

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: I'll cover them from the top of the casement.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: You're not coming with us?

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: Got a reason to stay.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: That reason wear a blue dress and work in the surgery?

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: It does and it is a better lookin' reason than you, Jack Winthrop.  Push hard, 'cos you got to clear the French outpost by dawn.  Good luck, Jack.

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: Let the children of the dead Colonel Munro go free and take the fire out of the English anger over the murder of their helpless ones.

turns.speaker: MAGUA
turns.text: Our father, Montcalm, is greater than the Yengeese in the arts of war. The Huron do not fear English anger.

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: Wise one, the French fathers made peace and swore to their honor not to break the friendship. Magua broke it. It is false that the French would not be friends, still, to the Huron.

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: So the Huron are the servants of the French?  To do what the French are shamed to do?

turns.speaker: MAGUA
turns.text: No.  Huron serve no one. The French father believes he fooled Magua because he is so proud of his cleverness, he is blind. But it is the Huron path that Magua walks down, not the French one... Now, Les Francais, also, fear Huron. That is good. When the Huron is strong from their fear, we will make the terms of trade with Les Francais. And we will trade as the white man trades. Take land from the Abnakes; fur from the Osage, Sauk & Fox. And make the Huron great. Over other tribes. No less than the whites, as strong as the whites.

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: Magua would use the ways of Les Francais and the Yengeese...

turns.speaker: MAGUA
turns.text: The red man put down the bow, picked up the fire stick and became the best warrior in the forest. Yes. It is the only way.

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: Would the Huron make his Algonquin brothers foolish with brandy and steal his lands to sell them for gold to the white man?  Would the Huron have greed for more land than a man can use? Like Francais Black Robes do?  Would Huron kill tribes with disease? Would the Huron fool Seneca into taking all the animals in the forest for beads & brandy? But sell the fur to the white man for gold?...  Those are the ways of Yengeese and Les Francais masters. Are they the ways of Huron men who hunt & work the land? Or of dogs?  ...Magua's heart is twisted. He would make himself into what twisted him. A Dog, become Master of Dogs. But are Hurons dogs?  ...Magua's way is false. It is like the white sickness. Magua's way will bring only sadness and shame. Is there another way? I don't know.  I am Nathaniel of the Yengeese; Hawkeye, adopted son of Chingachgook, of the Mohican people... Let the children of the dead Munro go free... I speak the truth.

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: Help ourselves to a few horns from your powder stores.

turns.speaker: MUNRO
turns.text: What else?

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: A man, here, can make a run straight through to Webb.

turns.speaker: MUNRO
turns.text: ...not enough time to get to Albany and back with reinforcements...

turns.speaker: MUNRO
turns.text: Yes, Mr. Poe? So?

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: It was a war party. It means they're on the attack up and down the frontier.

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: Many men here, their homes are in the path.

turns.speaker: MUNRO
turns.text: That's all, sir.

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: That judgment is not more important than their right under agreement with Webb to defend their farms & families... Major Heyward was at John Cameron's. He saw what it was.

turns.speaker: MUNRO
turns.text: What did you see, Major?

turns.speaker: MUNRO
turns.text: I'll have none of that!  Montcalm is a soldier and a gentleman. Not a butcher.

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: Easy for you to suppose. While it is their women and children, not yours, alone in their farms!

turns.speaker: MUNRO
turns.text: You forget yourself!

turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: I didn't experience anything so surprising from Bristol to Albany as what I witnessed here today.

turns.speaker: WEBB
turns.text: And what is that?

turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: The Crown "negotiating" the terms of service?

turns.speaker: WEBB
turns.text: I know.  One has to give Americans "reasons" and make agreements to get them to do anything at all.  Tiring, isn't it?  But that's the way of it here.

turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: I thought British policy is 'Make the World... England', sir.

turns.speaker: WEBB
turns.text: You will take command of the 62nd Regiment of Foot. At Fort William Henry under Colonel Munro. I will march the 33rd to Fort Edward.

turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: Sir!... Might I inquire if General Webb has heard from Colonel Munro's daughters? I was to rendezvous with them in Albany and escort them to the fort.

turns.speaker: WEBB
turns.text: Yes. You may.  You there. What does Munro call you?  The "Scotsman" has sent one of his Indian allies to guide you.

turns.speaker: WEBB
turns.text: The Scotsman's daughters are at the Poltroon's house. A company of the 33rd will accompany you and Magua will show you the way.

turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: By your leave, sir.

turns.speaker: MUNRO
turns.text: Does Webb not even know we are besieged?

turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: Sir. Webb has no idea. And he certainly does not know to send reinforcements!

turns.speaker: MUNRO
turns.text: What happened to you?

turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: Ambush... on the George Road. This Magua led us into it.  ...eighteen killed. It's these men who saved us. They guided us here...

turns.speaker: MUNRO
turns.text: Thank you. How can I reward you?

turns.speaker: MUNRO
turns.text: What a place for them...

turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: Might I enquire after the situation, sir, given that I've seen of the French engineering from the ridge above?

turns.speaker: MUNRO
turns.text: Logistics are his guns are bigger than mine and he has more of them. They keep our heads down while his sappers make thirty yards of trench a day. His thirteen inch mortars have a two hundred yard range, so when they're close enough, they'll move them in, lob explosive rounds over our walls and pound us to dust. They look to be three hundred yards out.  Bloody murderers.  You have three days.

turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: Webb's not in Albany. He marched the 33rd to Fort Edward two days ago.

turns.speaker: MUNRO
turns.text: Webb's at Edward?

turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: MUNRO
turns.text: Only twelve miles away! He could be here day after tomorrow.  Find your man, sir! Captain Beams will give you the message.

turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: Things were done. Nobody was spared...

turns.speaker: MUNRO
turns.text: Terrible feature of war in the Americas.  Best to keep your sight fixed on our duty.

turns.speaker: MUNRO
turns.text: Not with enough certainty to outweigh British interests in this fort.

turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: And who empowered these provincials to pass judgment upon England's policies in her own colonies? To come and go without so much as a "by your leave."

turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: This is the signature of Webb.  And I know the temper of our men. Rather than spend the war in a French prison hulk in Hudson Bay, they'd fight to the end.

turns.speaker: MUNRO
turns.text: You have heard your answer, Monsieur le Marquis.

turns.speaker: MUNRO
turns.text: I have lived to see two things I never expected.  An Englishman afraid to support a friend. And a Frenchman too honest to profit by that advantage.

turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: General Webb can burn in hell. We'll go back and dig our graves behind the ramparts! Our mission is to fight.

turns.speaker: MUNRO
turns.text: Death and honor are sometimes thought to be the same. Today I have learned that they are not.

turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: Sir!

turns.speaker: MUNRO
turns.text: The decision is final.

turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: Sergeant! Form three ranks!

turns.speaker: SERGEANT MAJOR
turns.text: Sir!  Upon the center, wheel to the left- about!  March!  Rear ranks, proper distance!  Front ranks, take your distance! March!  Halt!  Make ready!

turns.speaker: SERGEANT MAJOR
turns.text: First rank! Second rank! Present arms!

turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: Fire!!!

turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: Advance, Sergeant Major!

turns.speaker: SERGEANT MAJOR
turns.text: Sir!!!  Third rank! Twelve paces! Forward march!

turns.speaker: SERGEANT MAJOR
turns.text: Shoulder arms!  Present!

turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: Fire!!!

turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: Sergeant Major!

turns.speaker: SERGEANT MAJOR
turns.text: Sir!

turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: Thank you, Sergeant Major. Thank the men.

turns.speaker: SERGEANT MAJOR
turns.text: Atten-hut!

turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: Men are to stay in file, Sergeant Major!

turns.speaker: SERGEANT MAJOR
turns.text: Yes sir!

turns.speaker: SERGEANT MAJOR
turns.text: Right - about face! March! First rank present!

turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: Fire!

turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: We must... stop... soon. Women are... tired.  You... understand?

turns.speaker: MAGUA
turns.text: I understand. This is not good place to stop.  Two leagues from here. No water 'til then.  That where we stop. Better place.

turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: No. Stop in the glade just ahead! When the ladies are rested, we will proceed. Do you understand?

turns.speaker: MAGUA
turns.text: "Magua understand paleface is a dog to his women.  When his women want to eat, he lay aside his tomahawk to feed their laziness."

turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: Excuse me. What did you say?

turns.speaker: MAGUA
turns.text: Magua say: "Yes. Good idea."

turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: If Magua give women to Yengeese soldiers... will receive many gifts.

turns.speaker: MAGUA
turns.text: Gifts?

turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: Three, four oxen... much wampum.

turns.speaker: MAGUA
turns.text: Wampum?

turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: MAGUA
turns.text: Does Yengeese Major have property across salt sea?

turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: MAGUA
turns.text: Yengeese Major give all property to Magua.  Magua give Yengeese Major much wampum, many gifts, maybe three, four oxen.

turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: Gold could be arranged.

turns.speaker: MAGUA
turns.text: For Munro children?

turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: MAGUA
turns.text: How much gold has the master of the Yengeese?

turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: The King? The King has mountains of gold!

turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: What is enough?

turns.speaker: MAGUA
turns.text: Heart. Give Magua new heart.

turns.speaker: MUNRO
turns.text: I must receive proof more conclusive than Mr. Poe's opinion before I weaken our defenses by allowing militia to withdraw.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Chingachgook's of the same opinion. Taken together, that's gospel. Your fort will stand or fall depending on Webb and reinforcements, not these colonials' presence.

turns.speaker: MUNRO
turns.text: I judge military matters, Captain Winthrop, not you.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: We are not forgettin' Webb's promise!

turns.speaker: MUNRO
turns.text: British promises are honored. And the militia will not be released. Because I need more definite proof than this man's word!

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Nathaniel's word been good on the frontier a long time before you got here!

turns.speaker: MUNRO
turns.text: This interview's over! The militia stays!

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Does the rule of English law no longer govern?  Has it been replaced by absolutism?

turns.speaker: MONTCALM
turns.text: Why do hate the Grey Hair, Magua?

turns.speaker: MAGUA
turns.text: When the Grey Hair is dead, Magua will eat his heart. Before he dies Magua will put his children under the knife so the Grey Hair will see his seed is wiped out forever.

turns.speaker: MAGUA
turns.text: Is the hatchet buried between the English and my French father?

turns.speaker: MONTCALM
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: MAGUA
turns.text: Not a warrior has a scalp and the white men become friends.

turns.speaker: MONTCALM
turns.text: My master owns these lands and your father has been ordered to drive off the English squatters. They have consented to go. So now he calls them enemies no longer.

turns.speaker: MAGUA
turns.text: Magua took the hatchet to color it with blood.  It is still bright. Only when it is red, then it will be buried.

turns.speaker: MONTCALM
turns.text: But so many suns have set since Le Renard struck the war post. Is he not tired?

turns.speaker: MAGUA
turns.text: Where is that sun?! It has gone behind the hill.  It is dark and cold. It has set on his people, they are fooled and kill all the animals and sell all of their lands to enrich the European masters who are always greedy for more than they need.  And Le Subtil is the son of his tribe. There have been many clouds and many mountains. But now he has come to lead his nation.

turns.speaker: MONTCALM
turns.text: That Le Renard has the power to lead his people into the light, I know well.

turns.speaker: MONTCALM
turns.text: That's where a lead bullet has torn you.

turns.speaker: MAGUA
turns.text: And this?

turns.speaker: MONTCALM
turns.text: My son has been sadly injured. Who did this?

turns.speaker: MAGUA
turns.text: Magua slept hard in the English wigwams.  And the sticks left their mark...  Magua's village and lodges were burnt. Magua's children were killed by the English.  Magua was taken as a slave by the Mohawks who fought for the Grey Hair. Magua's wife believed he was dead and became the wife of another. The Grey Hair was the father of all this.  In time Magua became blood-brother to Mohawk to become free. In his heart he always was Huron.  And his heart will be whole again on the day when the Grey Hair and all his seed are dead!

turns.speaker: MONTCALM
turns.text: My son Magua's pain is my pain.

turns.speaker: MAGUA
turns.text: Does the chief of the Canadas believe the English will keep the terms?

turns.speaker: MONTCALM
turns.text: Munro would. But General Webb will not send their soldiers across the salt lake.  Having let them go, I fear I will only fight the same men again when I move south.  And yet, I cannot break the terms of the capitulation and sully the lilies of France...

turns.speaker: MAGUA
turns.text: Many things my French father cannot do, Magua can.

turns.speaker: MONTCALM
turns.text: Colonel Munro, I have known you as a gallant antagonist. I am happy to make your acquaintance as a friend.

turns.speaker: MUNRO
turns.text: And I to make yours, Monsieur le Marquis.

turns.speaker: MONTCALM
turns.text: Please accept my compliments for the strong and skillful defense of your fortress. Under the command of a lesser man it would have fallen long ago given the superior numbers and material... mere chance has allowed me to array against you...

turns.speaker: MUNRO
turns.text: Monsieur le Marquis, I am a soldier, not a diplomat. You called this parlay for a reason.

turns.speaker: MONTCALM
turns.text: You have already done everything which is necessary for the honor of your Prince. I will forever bear testimony that your resistance has been gallant and was continued as long as there was hope. But now, I beg you to listen to the admonitions of humanity. I beg you to consider my terms for your surrender.

turns.speaker: MUNRO
turns.text: However I may apprise such testimony from Monsieur Montcalm, Fort William Henry is strong and stands.

turns.speaker: MONTCALM
turns.text: Honor that is freely accorded to courage, may be refused obstinacy... These hills afford to us every opportunity to reconnoiter your works and I am possibly as well acquainted with your weak condition as you are yourselves.  Is Webb really en route and Montcalm hopes to take the fort by duplicity before British reinforcements arrive?

turns.speaker: MUNRO
turns.text: Perhaps the General's glasses can reach to the Hudson and he knows the size and imminence of the army of Webb...?

turns.speaker: MUNRO
turns.text: Such as...?

turns.speaker: MONTCALM
turns.text: My master requires the fort be destroyed.  But, for you and your comrades, there is no privilege that will be denied. None of your men will see the inside of a prison barge. They're free to go so long as they return to England and fight no more on this continent, and the civilian militia return to their farms.

turns.speaker: MUNRO
turns.text: Their arms?

turns.speaker: MONTCALM
turns.text: They may leave the fortress fully armed, but with no ammunition... Other than that, ask what you wish.

turns.speaker: MUNRO
turns.text: The honors of war?

turns.speaker: MONTCALM
turns.text: Granted.

turns.speaker: MUNRO
turns.text: My colors?

turns.speaker: MONTCALM
turns.text: Carry them to England to your King with pride.

turns.speaker: MUNRO
turns.text: Allow me to consult with my officers.

turns.speaker: MUNRO
turns.text: I am deeply touched by such unusual and unexpected generosity... The fort is yours under the condition that we be given until dawn to bury our dead, prepare our men and women for their march and turn our wounded over to your surgeon.

turns.speaker: MONTCALM
turns.text: Granted, Monsieur.

turns.speaker: SENTRY
turns.text: Qui vive?

turns.speaker: MONTCALM
turns.text: France.

turns.speaker: SENTRY
turns.text: Le mot d'ordre?

turns.speaker: MONTCALM
turns.text: La victoire.

turns.speaker: SENTRY
turns.text: C'est bien, vous vous promenez bien matin, monsieur!

turns.speaker: MONTCALM
turns.text: Il est necessaire d'etre vigilant, mon enfant.

turns.speaker: BECK
turns.text: Are you planning on working tomorrow?

turns.speaker: DOC
turns.text: Well, I'll be on the golf course in the morning.  Then, if I don't have any babies to deliver--

turns.speaker: BECK
turns.text: We almost had an accident today. DeJesus' suit...

turns.speaker: DOC
turns.text: You mind if I take a look at this?

turns.speaker: BECK
turns.text: Be my guest.

turns.speaker: BECK
turns.text: What do you want me to say? That it all sounds mysterious?

turns.speaker: DOC
turns.text: These observers were doing something. A test...I think they sank that ship on purpose to cover up their mistakes.

turns.speaker: BECK
turns.text: What mistakes?  Look, I think it's no big deal but if you want to find out why this ship sank have Maritime run a check.

turns.speaker: BECK
turns.text: What's wrong?

turns.speaker: DOC
turns.text: Pretty good imitation of a hangover and I ought to know.

turns.speaker: BECK
turns.text: Dead?  This morning you said he had some skin disorder.

turns.speaker: DOC
turns.text: He did.

turns.speaker: BECK
turns.text: Well, how the hell does a skin rash kill you in eight hours?!

turns.speaker: DOC
turns.text: Here.  Put this on.  You examine him.

turns.speaker: BECK
turns.text: I'm not a doctor.

turns.speaker: DOC
turns.text: For this...you don't need to be.

turns.speaker: BECK
turns.text: The mask is because you think it might be...catching?

turns.speaker: DOC
turns.text: I don't know.  I've been back and forth with Narragansett Naval all day, consulting with the best people in maritime medicine, the best people in viruses...

turns.speaker: BECK
turns.text: And?

turns.speaker: DOC
turns.text: And they didn't believe the symptoms I described...

turns.speaker: BECK
turns.text: Why Sixpack?

turns.speaker: DOC
turns.text: It could be a million things, something in the air, food....  But he went on that ship and so did Williams...  I want to examine the crew.

turns.speaker: BECK
turns.text: Yeah...right...

turns.speaker: BECK
turns.text: They found this?

turns.speaker: DOC
turns.text: No.  I think they isolated him in genetic engineering. Homo aquaticus...

turns.speaker: BECK
turns.text: Was there such a thing?

turns.speaker: DOC
turns.text: Danakil man?...one of our ancestors.  Named for the Danakil Alps in Ethiopia.

turns.speaker: BECK
turns.text: Not exactly a big ocean country.

turns.speaker: DOC
turns.text: It was when it counted a couple of million years ago when the seas came in and drove us into the water.  Most homo sapiens didn't make it...Danakil man... <u>adapted</u>.

turns.speaker: DOC
turns.text: Some say that's why we're basically hairless, for less water resistance, faster swimming speeds...

turns.speaker: BECK
turns.text: But what about those scales... or that leech-like thing that bit Cobb?

turns.speaker: DOC
turns.text: Why stop with just one aspect of marine life?  Why not incorporate the best genetic components the ocean has to offer?...

turns.speaker: BECK
turns.text: Well, if they were perfecting an aquaman, then why's there a dead one onboard that Russian ship?  Why isn't he out swimming around?

turns.speaker: BECK
turns.text: That it acquires intelligence from its victims?

turns.speaker: DOC
turns.text: Intelligence may not be the right word...

turns.speaker: DOC
turns.text: Be careful with it.

turns.speaker: BECK
turns.text: Don't worry, I don't want to give up any more.

turns.speaker: BECK
turns.text: DeJesus!  A readout!

turns.speaker: JONES
turns.text: He don't need a readout, man, he needs help!

turns.speaker: BECK
turns.text: Stay calm!

turns.speaker: BECK
turns.text: Doc eat already?

turns.speaker: JONES
turns.text: The good doctor hasn't showed yet.

turns.speaker: BECK
turns.text: I've been looking at the duty roster...at the shack hours outstanding...

turns.speaker: JONES
turns.text: Uh, oh...I see where this is going...

turns.speaker: BECK
turns.text: ...all of you owe time and I thought tonight would be a good time to---

turns.speaker: JONES
turns.text: Bullshit...I was just talking to him.  I saw him move.

turns.speaker: BECK
turns.text: What?...

turns.speaker: JONES
turns.text: We're getting out of here just in time.

turns.speaker: BECK
turns.text: There's now a problem with the weather for pickup.  There's a typhoon in our sector... ...We're going to be delayed twelve hours...

turns.speaker: JONES
turns.text: It's got Hazy!

turns.speaker: BECK
turns.text: What has?

turns.speaker: JONES
turns.text: One of those chunks of Sixpack!  Like a big leech, with those teeth!...

turns.speaker: BECK
turns.text: I thought they were your friends?

turns.speaker: JONES
turns.text: Were, Doss <u>were</u>.

turns.speaker: BECK
turns.text: No, it's not going through. The intercom's busted.  I thought DeJesus fixed that?

turns.speaker: JONES
turns.text: He did.

turns.speaker: BECK
turns.text: That's why there's a dead one on the ship.  It ran out of blood.

turns.speaker: JONES
turns.text: What dead one on the ship?

turns.speaker: BECK
turns.text: We don't have much choice... without air, the internal pressure will fall and--

turns.speaker: JONES
turns.text: Crunch...Implosion.

turns.speaker: JONES
turns.text: Jesus Christ...

turns.speaker: BECK
turns.text: Can you fix it?

turns.speaker: JONES
turns.text: No way...

turns.speaker: BECK
turns.text: Think!  Can we stop it?! Block it up?!  Shut down the line somewhere?!  Think!

turns.speaker: JONES
turns.text: I am thinking, man!  You think I want to die!  I am thinking!  I--

turns.speaker: JONES
turns.text: I hit it.  But I can't see it!  Can you see it?!

turns.speaker: BECK
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: BECK
turns.text: Go on!

turns.speaker: JONES
turns.text: No!

turns.speaker: BECK
turns.text: That's an order!

turns.speaker: JONES
turns.text: Fuck your orders!

turns.speaker: JONES
turns.text: Where the hell've you been?

turns.speaker: BECK
turns.text: I got hung up!  Try this!

turns.speaker: JONES
turns.text: Your suit, Becky!

turns.speaker: BECK
turns.text: Just get in yours!

turns.speaker: BECK
turns.text: Cobb, Jones, I want you to do something about that damn rattle in the air system...  Bowman and Sixpack...living quarters...

turns.speaker: SIXPACK
turns.text: Shit...

turns.speaker: BECK
turns.text: Williams...get DeJesus' suit on the "sick rack" and do a diagnostics.  Any other suit problems she should know about?

turns.speaker: SIXPACK
turns.text: Look at my foot, sir!  This bitch put a goddamn sea monster in my bunk!

turns.speaker: BECK
turns.text: How do you know it was Williams?

turns.speaker: SIXPACK
turns.text: Huh?  I...uh...uh...

turns.speaker: BECK
turns.text: All right, Sixpack, you and Williams are gonna pull water duty tomorrow--

turns.speaker: WILLIE
turns.text: You did good...

turns.speaker: BECK
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: WILLIE
turns.text: Today...with DeJesus.  That was smart thinking to get him inside...

turns.speaker: BECK
turns.text: There probably wasn't anything wrong with his suit...

turns.speaker: WILLIE
turns.text: Still...you did the right thing.

turns.speaker: BECK
turns.text: I need more light on that, Four.

turns.speaker: WILLIE
turns.text: Roger...  More light, Sixpack...

turns.speaker: BECK
turns.text: That's great.  Now let's move 35 degrees southwest.

turns.speaker: WILLIE
turns.text: You screw around like that again and--

turns.speaker: WILLIE
turns.text: Sixpack?

turns.speaker: BECK
turns.text: Why can't we pick up his signal?

turns.speaker: BECK
turns.text: That was a loud one wasn't it?

turns.speaker: WILLIE
turns.text: After a month of it you'd think I'd be used to it.

turns.speaker: BECK
turns.text: How's astronaut training?

turns.speaker: WILLIE
turns.text: Why?  You going to give me hard time like the others?

turns.speaker: BECK
turns.text: No.  I'm just being friendly.

turns.speaker: WILLIE
turns.text: Good...It's going good.

turns.speaker: BECK
turns.text: Whatever made you want to do a tour down here?

turns.speaker: WILLIE
turns.text: I need electrical field experience on my resume. Everything helps...  Why are you here?

turns.speaker: BECK
turns.text: Everybody in corporate training serves a tour on the line.  Sup- posed to hone leadership skills or something.

turns.speaker: WILLIE
turns.text: Has it helped?
